title: How to Make Cheese Sauce

steps.headline: Shred 4 ounces (110 g) of cold cheese.
steps.description: While cheddar is a common choice, you can use any kind of cheese or blend. Remove your cheese from the fridge. Lay down a piece of wax paper onto a flat surface. Hold a flat shredder over the paper 45 degrees to the surface. Place the cheese perpendicular to the shredder and, starting from the top, press downward on it while moving it toward the wax paper. Hold the shredder steady with one hand and firmly press the cheese down with your other as you drag it across the shredder. For parmesan and harder cheeses, hold the cheese 45 degrees to the wax paper. Afterward, drag a vegetable peeler from the top of the cheese down toward the bottom to scrape off larger shards. Use cold cheese whenever possible. As it sits it will lower to room temperature, which is ideal for when it's melted later. If you prefer to skip this step, purchase pre-shredded cheese.

steps.headline: Place the shredded cheese in a separate container.
steps.description: After you're done shredding your cheese, lift up the wax paper and gently pour the cheese into a container. Squeeze about 1/4 of a fresh lemon or 3 to 4 squirts from a store-bought container of lemon juice over it to ensure that it doesn't become stringy. Set the cheese aside to come to room temperature as you prepare your other toppings. This will facilitate the subsequent melting process.

steps.headline: Grate 1/2 teaspoon (2 grams) of fresh nutmeg for a spicy-sweet flavor.
steps.description: Place each piece of nutmeg onto a cutting board and crush it with the flat side of a kitchen knife. Afterward, peel away the shell until the nut is bare. Hold a flat shredder at a 45-degree angle to the cutting board. Grip the tip of the nutmeg seed with your forefinger and thumb and slide the edge of it down the shredder in 2 inch (51 mm) strokes. Continue grating your nutmegs until you have enough. Purchase store-bought ground nutmeg to skip the grating process. However, remember that pre-ground nutmeg can lose its flavor faster than whole nutmeg.

steps.headline: Dice up a half or full onion to give your cheese a mild bite.
steps.description: Cut off the sides of the onion with a kitchen knife and place it flat-side down onto a cutting board. Afterward, cut it in half lengthwise and peel the skin off. Place one half face down on the cutting board and make sure the root end is pointed away from you. Hold the left side with your left hand and make vertical cuts into the onion, moving from top to bottom and leaving a small portion uncut. Now, turn the onion half 90 degrees and cut it from the top to the bottom, moving from the right to left. Repeat the above process for the other half if you like. If you'd prefer just one half, wrap the unused portion in cling-wrap, and store it in the refrigerator for 7 to 10 days.

steps.headline: Cut 1.5 ounce (43 g) of butter into small pieces for heating.
steps.description: When the butter is in small pieces, it will melt faster and mix with flour better. Use a butter knife to cut off about 1.5 ounces (43 g) of butter and place it onto a cutting board. From here, cut it into small pieces about the size of your fingertip. Purchase pre-wrapped butter sticks for easier cutting.

steps.headline: Melt your butter pieces in a heavy saucepan at 195 °F (91 °C).
steps.description: Gently move each piece of butter into a small heavy saucepan and place it onto a stove element. Turn your stove to low heat, which is usually "2" on your stove ring or approximately 195 °F (91 °C). Use a heavy pan whenever possible for more even heat distribution.

steps.headline: Whisk the flour in with the melted butter and cook for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: Cradle the whisk between your thumb and forefinger and loop it around the pan in a circular motion. Allow the whisk's handle to move around in your hand slightly. Continue to whisk even after the flour has been incorporated to ensure that the floury taste is removed. Keep the heat low and cook the mixture for 1 to 2 minutes after the flour is whisked in. When the flour is lightly golden, you can move on to the next step. Maintain the cradling hand position while whisking to decrease the likelihood of your hand tiring out.

steps.headline: Mix in 2 cups (470 mL) of cold milk and whisk for 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Remove your milk from the fridge. Gently pour the milk into the saucepan while continuing to whisk. Be sure to whisk the milk in slowly and continuously until the mixture breaks into a simmer. At this point, it should be bubbly and thick. Be sure that the butter and flour mixture is hot prior to adding the milk. If it isn't, let it sit for 1 to 2 more minutes. Mixing the ingredients together at different temperatures ensures that they'll heat at a moderate pace and the cheese develops an optimal texture.

steps.headline: Season the sauce with nutmeg, onion, cloves, bay leaves, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Start by sprinkling in some salt and pepper to taste. From here, add your 1/2 teaspoon (2 grams) of freshly grated nutmeg and diced onions. Finally, add 1 sprinkle of ground clove and 1 crushed bay leaf. Add each seasoning one at a time and taste your sauce after mixing them in. Play with the ingredient amounts to get the flavor you desire.

steps.headline: Simmer the sauce for 8 to 10 minutes or until it has a smooth consistency.
steps.description: Once the sauce begins to boil and you see bubbles, turn the temperature down to "Min" or the lowest number on your dial. This should bring it to a simmer, which is just below the boiling point while still getting heated. Once the sauce has reached a smooth consistency, remove it from the heat. It's important that the sauce is not heated past what's necessary for melting, so err on the side of using less heat.

steps.headline: Mix in the shredded cheese without heat.
steps.description: After removing the saucepan from the heat, sprinkle in your shredded cheese and whisk it in. Continue whisking until the cheese returns to a smooth consistency. If the cheese isn't melting, return it to the pan and put it on low heat. However, make sure the heat is at the lowest possible setting, as reheating can cause the cheese to become stringy. Add the cheese at the last possible minute and only cook until it melts. Do not let the cheese boil or it will curdle and burn.

steps.headline: Strain out the seasonings if the sauce is chunky.
steps.description: If your sauce is chunky, you can remove some of the seasonings with a small spoon. At this point, the flavor of the seasonings should be mixed in. You can also place a strainer into a medium pot and place a cheesecloth into the strainer. Make sure that the cloth is large enough to cover the entire surface of the strainer and hang over its edges. From here, gently pour the cheese into the strainer. If you use a cheesecloth, you need to let the cheese sit for a few hours at room temperature, so use this option as a last resort.

steps.headline: Serve your cheese sauce and refrigerate leftovers.
steps.description: Pour the cheese sauce over your favorite pasta or use it to make homemade Philly cheese steak sandwiches. For sides, use it as a dipping sauce with fries, pour it over nachos, or drizzle it over a mixed vegetable bowl of broccoli and cauliflower. If you have leftovers, place them into a sealed container and store it in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days. Reheat your sauce in a microwave-safe container on high for 1 to 2 minutes or reheat it in a saucepan at 195 °F (91 °C) for about 5 minutes.
